description:
Chryseobacterium wanjuense is a species of bacteria that was first isolated from soil samples collected in Wanju, South Korea. It belongs to the genus Chryseobacterium, which is a group of Gram-negative, aerobic, and non-spore-forming bacteria.

The cells of C. wanjuense are rod-shaped and exhibit a yellow pigmentation due to the production of carotenoid compounds. This species is capable of growing at temperatures ranging from 4°C to 37°C, with an optimal growth temperature around 30°C.

Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequencing has shown that C. wanjuense is closely related to other Chryseobacterium species, such as Chryseobacterium indologenes and Chryseobacterium gleum. However, it can be distinguished from these related species by its unique biochemical and physiological characteristics.

C. wanjuense has been found to possess various enzymatic activities, including the production of lipases, proteases, and xylanases, which may contribute to its potential applications in biotechnology and industrial processes. Further research is needed to fully understand the ecological role and potential applications of this bacterial species.
